1.36.text:
Hi, I'm Rick Steves, back with more of the
best of Europe. This time we're in Switzerland

6.30.text:
enjoying not its majestic Alps...but its
fascinating cities.

42.76.text:
Whether enjoying its traditional culture high
in the mountains

45.06.text:
or savoring the joys of modern life in its
great cities,

47.85.text:
the Swiss get it right.
In this episode we focus on an often overlooked

51.92.text:
side part of Switzerland -
its urban charm.

54.85.text:
We'll get some easy exercise - floating with
locals...and ring one very big bell. We'll

62.21.text:
enjoy a variety of art from stained glass
by Marc Chagall, to bold works by artists

67.24.text:
considered insane. We'll see how the Swiss
use blue lights as part of a creative drug

73.89.text:
policy and explore a secret underground fortress
built as a defense against the Nazis. And,

81.14.text:
we'll experience that incomparable Swiss natural
beauty with a cruise on a romantic paddle

88.58.text:
Nestled in the center of Europe is Switzerland.
While much of the country is dominated by

93.48.text:
the Alps, most of its population is in the
northwest - a gentler land of lakes and cities.

99.80.text:
From Zürich we travel to Luzern, Bern, and
Lausanne.

105.21.text:
Like many visits to Switzerland, ours starts
in its biggest city - Zürich. While it's

108.13.text:
a major transportation hub and many just pass
through, it's a powerhouse city and well worth

115.37.text:
The Swiss joke that Zürich is zu reich and
zu ruhig - that's a play on German words for

121.52.text:
"too rich" and "too quiet." Sure it's rich...and
there are livelier places, but Zürich is

127.52.text:
comfortable and it consistently ranks as one
of the world's most livable cities.

133.91.text:
Zürich's history goes back to Roman times.
By the 19th century it was a leading European

140.28.text:
financial and economic center. Its people
are known for their wealth and for working

145.68.text:
hard to earn it. Like most Swiss cities, it
embraces its river or lake in a fun-loving

152.09.text:
way. The lakefront is a springboard for romantic
walks, bike rides, and cruises. A great way

159.73.text:
to glide across town is to catch the riverboat,
which functions like a city bus, and just

167.97.text:
Its old town is lively day and night with
cafés, galleries, and a colorful cobbled

172.64.text:
ambience. Zürich's main drag, Bahnhofstrasse,
is famous for its elegant shops. If you're

179.73.text:
looking for a fancy watch, stunning jewelry,
or a $1,000 sweater...this is the place.

187.32.text:
For more affordable extravagance - these delightful
mini-macarons - a local favorite - may be

192.21.text: expensive...but they won't break the bank.

199.56.text:
The city's art treasure is in its Fraumünster
(or "Church of Our Lady"): a set of five towering

204.69.text:
stained glass windows by Marc Chagall. His
inimitable painting style - deep colors, simple

211.59.text:
figures, and shard-like Cubism - is perfectly
suited for the medium of stained glass.

217.34.text:
The windows depict Bible scenes - here Jacob
dreams of his ladder - the traffic of angels

223.58.text:
symbolizing the connection between God above
and Jacob's descendants (the Children of Israel)

230.19.text:
below. Old Testament images - King David with
his harp, Moses with the Ten Commandments,

236.97.text:
and the angel blowing the ram's horn to announce
the creation of a new Jerusalem, all create

241.79.text:
a cohesive message drawing you to the central
window. Here, a jumble of events from Christ's

247.30.text:
life leads to the central figure in God's
plan of salvation - a crucified yet ascendant

255.37.text:
But nearby, the leading entertaining heavenly
character in Zürich is its guardian angel.

261.86.text:
Hovering above the main hall in the central
train station, she protects all travelers

266.05.text:
and adds to the energy of the station. Situated
at the center of Western Europe, this major

272.86.text:
European transportation hub handles 2,000
trains a day zipping people all over Europe.

280.99.text:
Shortly after leaving Zürich, the train ride
becomes a scenic joyride. And 30 minutes later

292.65.text:
Since the Romantic era in the 19th century,
Luzern has been a regular stop on the "Grand

297.60.text:
Tour" route of Europe. Its inviting lakefront
now includes a modern concert hall - which

303.27.text:
incorporates the lake into its design. The
old town, with a pair of picture-perfect wooden

311.17.text:
bridges, straddles the Reuss River where it
tumbles out of Lake Lucerne.

323.27.text:
The bridge was built at an angle in the 14th
century to connect the town's medieval fortifications.

328.52.text:
Today it serves strollers rather than soldiers
as a peaceful way to connect two sides of

334.18.text:
town. Many are oblivious to the fascinating
art just overhead.

339.33.text:
Under the rafters hang about 100 colorful
17th-century paintings showing scenes from

343.58.text:
Luzern and its history. This legendary giant
dates to the Middle Ages, when locals discovered

349.18.text:
mammoth bones which they mistakenly thought
were the bones of a human giant. Here's Luzern

355.69.text:
in about 1400 - the bridge, already part of
the city fortifications. And Luzern looked

364.15.text:
Luzern is responsible for controlling the
lake level. By regulating the flow of water

368.45.text:
out of its lake, the city prevents the flooding
of lakeside villages when the snow melts.

372.90.text:
In the mid-19th century, the city devised
and built this extendable dam. By adding and

381.59.text:
taking away these wooden slats, they could
control the level of the lake.

389.13.text:
Swans are a fixture on the river today. Locals
say they arrived in the 17th century as a

394.24.text:
gift from the French king Louis XIV in appreciation
for the protection his Swiss Guards gave him.

401.26.text:
Switzerland has a long history of providing
strong and loyal warriors to foreign powers.

406.59.text:
The city's famous Lion Monument recalls the
heroism of more Swiss mercenaries. The mighty

412.35.text:
lion rests his paws on a French shield. Tears
stream down his cheeks. The broken-off end

418.20.text:
of a spear is slowly killing the noble beast.
The sad lion is a memorial to over 700 Swiss

424.59.text:
mercenaries who were killed defending Marie-Antoinette
and Louis XVI during the French Revolution.

434.52.text:
The people of Luzern take full advantage of
their delightful river with a variety of cafés

439.02.text:
and restaurants along its banks. This evening,
we're enjoying the setting as much as the

444.25.text:
food. I'm having the local pork. My producer
Simon is having eel fresh from the river.

455.01.text:
With a picturesque setting like this, the
dining experience makes for a wonderful memory.

467.37.text:
Boats connect towns around Lake Lucerne. That's
its English name, but the Swiss call it the

472.54.text:
Vierwaldstättersee - literally, "Lake of
the Four Forest Cantons." That's because it

478.45.text:
lies at the intersection of four of Switzerland's
cantons or states. Romantics will want to

484.56.text:
ride one of the classic paddleboat steamers.
A short ride drops you at any number of interesting

489.78.text: sights - one of which come with a surprise.

494.42.text:
Imagine it's 1941. You're Swiss; your country
is completely surrounded by Hitler and Mussolini.

505.08.text:
The Nazis are on the move. What to do? [knock,
knock] Turn your mountains into a hidden fortress.

512.26.text:
The Swiss managed to make their rugged mountains
an even more effective barrier. How? By lots

519.60.text:
One example, the Fortress Fürigen has done
its duty. Recently decommissioned, it now

524.63.text:
welcomes visitors interested in Switzerland's
secret defenses.

528.07.text:
Guide: In central Switzerland we have now
nine forts like this, bigger ones and smaller

535.62.text:
ones. There are installed I think in total
44 canons.

541.24.text:
The Swiss implemented a plan to retreat into
the mountainous heart of the country and defend

545.03.text:
themselves with a series of hidden fortresses
dug into mountain sides like this one.

550.12.text:
Guide: Here we enter into bunker #2. You see
here the canon. You can turn it, the elevation...

559.81.text:
Rick: I can sit here on the gun. Can I sit
on this?

562.77.text:
Guide: Yeah you can.
Rick: Push this down? 62-

567.80.text:
Guide: Fine, yeah.
Rick: And then I go, I want to go to 21.

574.77.text:
Guide: Fine, yes.
Rick: Wow there it is, 62 21, the top of the

580.05.text:
With the advent of the Cold War in the 1950s,
the fortress was retooled for the threat of

584.50.text:
the USSR. The Swiss have since found documents
indicating that both the Nazis and the Soviets

590.71.text: actually had plans to invade Switzerland.

593.69.text:
Guide: This is the bedroom for 100 soldiers;
50 beds, they have to share it because they

600.66.text:
have to work in shifts. This is the dining
room and over here the kitchen. And all these

606.95.text:
rooms and other forts have been built for
survival of Switzerland. Hitler took Belgium,

614.05.text:
Netherlands and we had the feeling we are
next.

620.21.text:
Wandering through this hidden fortress you're
reminded how perilous Switzerland's position

623.65.text:
was in the 20th century and how committed
the Swiss were to defending their freedom.

633.71.text:
Switzerland is laced together by an efficient
train system. Its trains are fast, frequent,

638.46.text:
and easy to use - taking you effortlessly
and scenically from downtown to downtown.

643.94.text: Our next stop: the capital city...Bern.

648.95.text:
The city of Bern is built on a peninsula created
by a hairpin turn of the Aare River.

655.65.text:
Its pointy towers and arcaded streets make
it one of Europe's finest surviving medieval

661.19.text:
towns. Bern is stately but accessible, classy
but fun.

667.39.text:
The city, founded in 1191, has managed to
avoid war damage and hasn't burned down since

674.18.text:
1405. After that fire, wooden buildings were
discouraged, and Bern gained its gray-green

683.91.text:
Colorful 16th-century fountains are Bern's
trademark. They were commissioned to brighten

688.85.text:
up the stony cityscape, to show off the town's
wealth, and to remind citizens of local heroes

694.65.text:
and events. The city is named for its mascot,
a bear - and bears are a reoccurring theme

705.57.text:
This famous clock tower was part of the main
gate of the original town wall. One side of

711.44.text:
it has a playful mechanical show, appropriate
in this country famous for its time pieces.

716.94.text:
The clock, which dates back to 1530, still
performs each hour. While you can see the

731.31.text:
medieval clock mechanism from inside - fascinating
in this land of clock and watch makers - most

736.45.text:
people enjoy the show from outside. At the
top of the hour the rooster crows... the bears

745.07.text:
promenade as the happy jester comes to life.
Father Time turns his hourglass and the rooster

753.04.text:
crows once more...as he has for about 500
years. In its day, this was a high-tech marvel.

761.17.text:
In this elegant city, you may brush elbows
with some high-powered legislators, but you

765.03.text:
wouldn't know it. Everything feels casual
for a national capital. The Swiss are very

771.34.text: comfortable with their own style of democracy.

774.66.text:
The Swiss government is a bicameral system
actually inspired by the United States Constitution,

779.31.text:
with one big difference: Executive power is
shared by a committee of seven, with a rotating

784.54.text:
ceremonial president and a passion for consensus.
This is a mechanism to avoid a power grab

790.12.text:
by a single individual...a safeguard that
the Swiss believe strengthens and protects

796.37.text:
Observant travelers will notice how the Swiss
government deals with its social problems

800.40.text:
with pragmatism and innovation. Too many cars
and chronically unemployed people? Create

805.91.text:
a program providing free loaner bikes...run
by people who would otherwise be collecting

814.92.text:
Like the United States, Switzerland is dealing
with a persistent drug abuse problem. The

819.05.text:
Swiss believe the purpose of a nation's drug
policy should be to reduce the harm drugs

823.50.text:
cause their society. Like many Europeans,
they treat substance abuse more as a health

828.28.text:
problem than a criminal problem. Rather than
fill their jails, the Swiss employ methods

832.78.text:
they find are both more compassionate and
more pragmatic.

836.84.text:
For instance, to help fight the spread of
AIDS and other diseases, street-side vending

841.75.text:
machines dispense government-subsided needles
- cheap and safe. There are needle-disposal

848.57.text:
boxes. Many public toilets are lit by blue
lights. If users can't find their veins, they'll

856.52.text:
shoot up elsewhere - it's hoped at heroin
maintenance centers, which provide addicts

860.65.text:
with counseling, clean needles, and a safe
alternative to the streets.

866.08.text:
And casual use of marijuana is tolerated.
Locals pass joints with no apparent worries

871.15.text:
in the shadow of the cathedral ignored by
others who simply enjoy life in a society

875.68.text:
that believes tolerating alternative lifestyles
makes more sense than building more prisons.

881.65.text:
Bern's cathedral is capped with a 330-foot-tall
tower, the highest in Switzerland. While it

887.95.text:
was built as a Catholic church, later in the
16th century with the Reformation, it became

892.77.text:
Protestant - that's why it is so sparsely
decorated.

899.00.text:
The Swiss Protestants were iconoclasts - they
considered statues of saints and Catholic

903.91.text:
art to be false idols - distractions from
God - and destroyed them. This church was

908.96.text:
originally adorned with 26 different little
chapels and altars each dedicated to a different

913.47.text:
saint or the Virgin Mary. When the Reformation
came to town in 1528...all that was swept

918.35.text:
away. The focus was shifted away from images
and to the pulpit from where Protestant preachers

923.85.text:
shared the Word of God not in Latin...but
in the people's language.

930.38.text:
Browsing through this barren place of worship,
you can sense the effectiveness of one man

934.72.text:
preaching from the pulpit to an undistracted
congregation.

939.88.text:
Climbing the spire, you'll see Protestants
had absolutely no problem with great bells.

945.13.text:
Guide: This is the biggest bell of Switzerland
and it's over 10 tons. And we are also very

952.69.text:
proud that we have the highest tower of Switzerland.
It's over 100 meters, exactly 101 meters.

973.00.text:
Art lovers enjoy Bern's Paul Klee Center.
With its wavy building mirroring the wavy

978.08.text:
landscape, Italian architect Renzo Piano's
building celebrates the creative spirit of

982.96.text:
the Swiss-born artist Paul Klee. While famous
as a painter, Klee embraced all forms of creative

989.88.text:
expression. The center - which fosters music
and theater as well as the visual arts - has

995.33.text:
a mission: to bring art to the people. A generous
zone is devoted to a children's workshop.

1002.29.text:
Kids love Paul Klee...and kids always teach
the art snobs a thing or two with their interpretations.

1008.34.text: The shadow theater sparks young imaginations.

1011.53.text:
Artistically, you just can't put Klee in a
box. His paintings - mostly from the 1920s

1017.27.text:
and '30s - are playful yet enigmatic. Audio
guides let you enjoy Klee's favorite music

1031.01.text:
as you wander through his paintings. He experimented
in pointillism - as you see in Ad Parnassum.

1039.09.text:
His art is full of symbolism...or maybe we
just think so.

1043.71.text:
Insula Dulcamara - literally "bittersweet
island" - is a good example of Klee's abstract

1048.86.text:
hieroglyph style. It's a puzzle - he pairs
opposites...man, woman...air, water. It's

1057.46.text:
1938...is that a submarine on the horizon
evoking the rise of Fascism? Perhaps the black

1062.96.text:
figures are death in a spring-like landscape,
which is eternal.

1072.58.text:
And when the sun comes out, it seems everyone's
heading for the banks of the Aare River. The

1077.60.text:
riverside park is a lively playground. The
Bernese, proud of their very clean river and

1083.09.text:
their basic ruddiness, have a tradition - sort
of a wet paseo. On summer days, they hike

1089.69.text: upstream, then float back into town.

1093.83.text:
For something to write home about, join the
locals and the trout in a float down the river.

1122.84.text:
Our final big city visit is another hour away
by train.

1128.82.text:
Lausanne perches elegantly overlooking Lake
Geneva. The city is made of two charming zones:

1139.29.text:
the idyllic waterfront and the tangled and
historic old town. Locals nickname their town

1145.60.text:
the San Francisco of Switzerland for all its
hills. There's no way to see it without lots

1151.18.text:
of climbing. Lausanne's pedestrianized Rue
de Bourg has the finest shops. By the way,

1166.58.text:
be careful with the pronunciation, many confuse
Lausanne with Luzern.

1173.60.text:
Lausanne's collection of fringe art - or Art
Brut - fills one of Europe's most thought-provoking

1182.02.text:
It presents works by self-taught creators
who, for various reasons, escaped cultural

1186.46.text:
conditioning and social conformity. The people
who made this art were completely untrained

1191.60.text: - as free-spirited as artists can be.

1195.16.text:
These pieces were created by amateur artists
- many who were labeled (and even locked up)

1200.28.text:
by society as "insane" or even "criminally
insane." Thumbnail biographies of these outsiders

1212.52.text:
In the 1940s, the artist Jean Dubuffet began
collecting art produced by people he called

1217.87.text:
"free from artistic culture and free from
fashion tendencies." Dubuffet said, "The art

1224.22.text:
does not lie in beds ready-made for it. It
runs away when its name is called. It wants

1229.86.text:
to be incognito. Its best moments are when
it forgets what it's called."

1241.91.text:
There's nothing incognito about Lausanne's
cathedral - the biggest church in Switzerland.

1246.80.text:
This is another example of a Swiss Protestant
church. Once again, it was built Catholic

1252.06.text:
and dedicated to Mary. But when the Reformation
hit, Swiss reformers purged it of religious

1257.58.text:
ornamentation - colorfully frescoed walls
were whitewashed, stained glass windows trashed,

1263.52.text: statues of Mary and the saints smashed.

1266.65.text:
Today, the church remains clean of images
- with the exception of an extravagant pipe

1272.14.text:
organ - its 7,000 pipes evoking the trumpets
of Jericho and the wings of angels.

1282.48.text:
For six centuries a watchman has called the
churches tower home. His job: to watch for

1287.16.text:
fires and to call out the hours. Since the
last big fire, a watchman has manned this

1293.83.text:
post...the last one of its kind in Switzerland.
Each night he steps onto his balcony and hollers

1299.29.text: Watchman: [Calling the hour in Swiss German]

1310.31.text:
The real charm of Lausanne lies on its lakefront,
a district called Ouchy. What was once an

1315.54.text:
aristocratic promenade is now the happy domain
of commoners, office workers and roller skaters

1321.62.text:
strutting their stuff. Romantic old-time steamers
connect travelers scenically to points all

1331.55.text:
around Lake Geneva. On a crisp day you can
see the French Alps; Chamonix and Mount Blanc

1341.32.text:
Ouchy's sightseeing highlight is a fine park
and museum devoted to the Olympic Games. This

1351.04.text:
museum celebrates the colorful history of
the Olympics and the founder of the modern

1355.53.text:
games, Pierre de Coubertin. In 1896, after
a 1,500 year lapse - and in the spirit of

1361.96.text: world peace - he restarted the games.

1366.64.text:
The exhibit traces the history of the Olympics.
Artifacts recall its original ancient Greek

1372.81.text:
beginnings. A century's worth of ceremonial
torches speaks to the resilient majesty of

1380.19.text:
an event that endeavors to bring the world
together. Highlights from past Olympiads rekindle

1386.87.text:
the thrill of these quadrillenial games. A
section dedicated to the Paralympics celebrates

1393.14.text:
recent inclusivity. Sports fans enjoy recalling
their heroes: from the track shoes Carl Lewis

1400.41.text:
used in the 1984 LA games to the skates of
Sonja Henie - the 13-year-old Norwegian ice

1406.50.text:
queen. Surveying gear from each sport, you
can follow the evolution of equipment that

1411.63.text: was clearly state of the art...in its day.

1415.48.text:
And you can complete your tour with a look
at how the bronze, silver and gold medals

1425.48.text:
From the elegant extravagance of Zürich....
to Luzern, with its iconic wooden bridges....

1432.85.text:
and from Bern, the country's fun-loving capital,
to Lausanne with its gorgeous lakeside setting,

1440.71.text: Swiss cities are a treat to visit.

1448.33.text:
As we've seen, there's far more to this country
than its towering Alpine peaks. No visit to

1453.28.text:
Switzerland is really complete without sampling
its urban charms as well. Thanks for joining

1457.83.text:
us. I'm Rick Steves. Until next time...keep
on traveling. Auf wiedersehen.

1464.43.text:
Guide: There are some others that are still
secret.

1467.59.text:
Rick: Still secret today?
Guide: Yes.

1469.58.text:
Rick: Ah where are they? [Laugh]
Guide: I don't know.

[Singing] I'm Popeye the sailor man, excuse
me.
